all_paragraphs: There is a special kind of beauty that occurs when entirely different concepts, theories of branches of human knowledge reveal themselves to be, in fact, intimately connected. In a letter to his friend, the mathematician Marcel Grossman, Albert Einstein wrote:
“It is a glorious feeling to discover the unity of a set of phenomena that seem at first to be completely separate.” — Albert Einstein

In this article, I will describe some incredibly elegant connections between two fundamental branches of theoretical physics, namely, quantum mechanics (QM), which represents the Universe at the levels of atoms and subatomic particles, and statistical mechanics (SM), which applies statistical methods to describe the behavior of collections of particles.

Mathematically these connections are a consequence of a simple arithmetical substitution which makes cyclic imaginary time equivalent to temperature. Putting it in another way, periodicity in imaginary time is equivalent to (the inverse of) temperature.
“A hidden connection is stronger than an obvious one.”

It is also noteworthy that if we simply extend our theories to include imaginary time, a host of striking results are obtained quite straightforwardly. Not only that but several mathematical objects become much better-behaved (this leads to some questioning regarding the “reality of time” which I will touch upon at the end of this essay).

A famous example (which will be described in much more detail lately) is the calculation of the temperature of the black hole radiation (the so-called Hawking radiation), obtained trivially by a simple arithmetical manipulation!

This “Euclideanization” of the interval has its origin in a seminal paper published in 1908 by the German mathematician Hermann Minkowski. There he famously declared
“Henceforth space by itself, and time by itself, are doomed to fade away into mere shadows, and only a kind of union of the two will preserve an independent reality. “
It was in this article that he actually “welded” time and space into the 4-dimensional construction we call spacetime.

The Boltzmann distribution can be derived in different ways. One derivation that is particularly interesting and is related to concepts in information theory, uses the so-called principle of maximum entropy. This principle, introduced by the American physicist E.T. Jaynes, states that the probability distribution which best represents the knowledge of a system is the one with the largest entropy. Applied to statistical mechanics it gives the Boltzmann distribution.

The Lagrangian approach was initially conceived as a reformulation of Newtonian mechanics. Though it produces the same results as the Newtonian approach, it does so emphasizing a completely different set of ideas. Furthermore, it has two significant advantages: it is mathematically more elegant and at the same time much more powerful when dealing with more complex systems.

Though this approach was introduced with classical (non-quantum) physics in view, it only revealed its full power much later, in the context of 20th-century quantum field theory. As it turns out, one can derive all fundamental laws of physics currently known using the “least action principle” which is, as we shall see below, dependent on the Lagrangian.
The Lagrangian function L is defined on what is called the configuration space C (technically, L is defined on what mathematicians call the tangent bundle of C, but let us ignore that for now).

Let us consider a system of N particles. Each point Q ∈ C corresponds to some configuration of the N particles (see the figure above). Note that the motion of Q encapsulates the dynamics of the full N-particle system. For concreteness, you can think of the Sun-Earth-Moon system in which case N is 3. Each Q ∈ C represents the positions and velocities of the three bodies.
The point Q moves around C following some law and this law can be obtained from the Lagrangian function L. The Lagrangian is, in general, a multivariate function that can be written as follows:
The first subset of arguments of the function
are the positions of the N particles. The second subset

are their velocities. Note that these variables do not necessarily have to be the run-of-the-mill cartesian coordinates. For that reason, they are called generalized coordinates and can be anything from angles to arc lengths along the particle trajectories (see the figure below).
The Lagrangian of a system is equal to the difference between its kinetic energy K (due to its motion) and its potential energy V (due to its position relative to other systems):
A simple example would be a particle with coordinate q(t) in a potential V(q):

There is a second approach which also exquisitely and powerfully reformulates classical mechanics. As in the Lagrangian picture, this approach is based on a single function, called the Hamiltonian H, from which one can derive the dynamics of physical systems (the equations that describe their motion). The Hamiltonian is defined in phase space. Similar to the configuration space, one can define the phase space as “a space in which all possible states of a system are represented, with each possible state corresponding to one unique point in the phase space.”
In phase space, a point is described by the position and the (generalized) momentum of the particles (instead of the time derivative of the positions):
Here, the momenta are obtained from the Lagrangian (you can read more about it here):

In quantum mechanics, the coordinates q and momenta p which describe motion in the classical phase space (see the item above), become operators. For example, the momentum becomes the following differential operator:

It is a well-known fact that quantum mechanics is based on probabilities. Einstein famously said:
“The theory says a lot, but does not really bring us any closer to the secret of the “old one.” I, at any rate, am convinced that He does not throw dice.”

In quantum mechanics, probabilities are the modulus squared of certain quantities known as quantum probability amplitudes. The animation below shows the time evolution of a very particular quantum state (or wave function) known as a coherent state (which closely resembles a classical object):

In physics, the action S is a quantity associated with the dynamics of a system. From S, one can derive the system’s equations of motion. Mathematically, it is a functional which take as its argument the history (or path) of the system and outputs a real number. More concretely, the action is represented by an integral of the Lagrangian over time
One of the most powerful ideas in physics is called the principle of least action according to which the actual path taken by the system is an extremum or stationary point of the action S:

As an alternative to the quantum mechanics formalism developed by Schrödinger and Heisenberg, the American physicist Richard Feynman created the so-called path integral formulation. In such formulation, the path integral used to calculate the probability amplitude that a particle goes from a point I to a point F, must consider literally all possible paths. For instance, these paths include trajectories that go forward and backward in time! To obtain the total probability amplitude one assigns to each possible path q(t) an amplitude

More precisely the total amplitude is a functional integral over an infinite number of trajectories or paths. When the oscillating contributions are summed inside the path integral we expect cancellations to occur. More precisely, what happens is that the paths close to the classical one, obtained when we take the limit

have a strong in-phase contribution which implies that the stationary path is dominant, and quantum fluctuations (or corrections) are mostly associated with paths that are close to the classical path (see this reference for more details).

We should point out that the path integral integration measure, given by the curly D, has serious convergence issues as we increase to ∞ the number of incremental time steps needed to build the alternative paths and derive the path integral. We will come back to this issue.

All particles in the Universe are excitations of quantum fields and any endeavor to explain the fundamental laws governing the behavior of elementary particles must take into account the basic tenets of quantum field theory or QFT, the conceptual framework on which the physics of elementary particles (such as quarks and electrons) is based. Furthermore, many scientists believe that the Theory of Everything (TOE) will be some kind of quantum field theory (on steroids).
All particles in the Universe are excitations of quantum fields.

In non-perturbative physics, the Euclideanization brings a host of interest applications (they will be described in great detail below).

I will now describe some striking results obtained using Wick rotations in the context of general relativity (GR), which is Einstein’s theory of gravity. The correspondence between thermal states and periodicity in Euclidean time is particularly noteworthy in GR where the periodicity is interpreted geometrically, as we shall see.

Euclidean quantum gravity (EQG) is an approach to quantum gravity using Wick rotations. As in Euclidean quantum field theory, one defines path integrals in imaginary time over positive definite metrics based on the belief that the topology of the gravitational field is required.

EQG is an example of “reduction of physics to geometry” and provides an efficient and often extremely elegant way of obtaining non-perturbative information about quantum gravity. It had several successes including:

One place where the correspondence has a clear geometrical interpretation is in the physics of black holes. I will now briefly show how to calculate the temperature of the radiation emitted by black holes using Euclidean time.

In 1974, Stephen Hawking published a groundbreaking paper (see the figure below) where he showed that, when quantum mechanical effects are considered near the event horizon, black holes emit radiation (the so-called Hawking radiation).
In the vicinity of a static black hole, the spacetime metric becomes the so-called Schwarzschild metric:
where, in the last term, dΩ denotes a small solid angle (see the figure below).
Far from the black hole, the metric becomes
This is the Minkowski metric in spherical coordinates.
The event horizon of the black hole is at the Schwarzschild radius given by
At the event horizon, something quite unexpected happens: the signs of the first and second coefficients change sign. This implies that space and time are effectively interchanged.
At the event horizon of a black hole, space and time are effectively interchanged.

Now, since in the vacuum near the black hole there are quantum fluctuations, which is the production of virtual particle-antiparticle pairs, what often occurs is that one of the particles of the pair falls into the black hole while the other particle does not.

There is an apparent caveat here. One of the main tenets of quantum mechanics, the uncertainty principle, limits the amount of time a virtual pair can exist. This behavior of the particle-antiparticle pair seems to contradict it. This apparent contradiction is resolved by the fact that the swapping of space and time is accompanied by a corresponding one between energy and momentum. Hence, the meaning of energy changes and the uncertainty principle is not violated.

In one interprets the Universe as a quantum mechanical system it must have a wave function Ψ. Analogously to the Schrödinger equation in ordinary quantum mechanics, Ψ obeys the so-called Wheeler–DeWitt equation given by:

In this equation, which is deceptively simple, the operator H is called Hamiltonian constraint in a quantized version of general relativity. The operator H does not govern time evolution and therefore the Schrödinger equation is not valid. Furthermore, the wave function is not the traditional one from ordinary quantum mechanics and is, instead, a function of the field configurations on the whole spacetime (see this reference for more details).
Though the Wheeler–DeWitt equation is pathological in general, it is well defined in some in some important cases.

Though a full-fledged quantum gravity theory is not completely known yet, physicists believe that it will contain the Feynman path integral formulation as one of its ingredients. The Lorentzian path integral (before Wick rotating) has the form:

We can show that often one is able to recover the Wheeler–DeWitt equation from this path integral.

After complexification, the geometries involved become Euclidean (or more precisely Riemannian). In fact, to obtain a well-defined classical boundary-value problem (a differential equation together with a set of boundary conditions) for the vacuum equations of general relativity one can show that Euclidean four-geometries are needed, instead of Lorentzian ones.

These results are examples of the “reduction of thermodynamics to geometry”.

Now, what are the boundary conditions of the Wheeler–DeWitt equation? They are quantum conditions, and the two more popular are the “no-boundary proposal” and the “tunneling proposal”. Let us restrict our discussion the “no-boundary proposal” of Stephen Hawking and the American physicist James Hartle.

The singularity theorems proved by Stephen Hawking and Roger Penrose, predict that, given certain conditions, classical spacetimes are singular at the origin of time. This implies that the general relativity is not a complete theory and some specification regarding what occurs when the singularity is hit must be provided.
In a famous paper, Hawking and Hartle suggested a way to deal with this issue. Their so-called Hartle–Hawking state, given by,
is a wave function of the Universe and it is obtained via a Euclidean path integral. They suggest a boundary condition for the initial state of the Universe known as the no-boundary proposal.
The interpretation of this path integral is that it gives the probability of a Universe with specific characteristics to be created from nothing.
The Hartle-Hawking wave function gives the probability of a Universe with specific characteristics to be created from nothing.”

Many physicists strongly suspect that there is something quite deep underlying this correspondence, something that we haven’t been able to fully grasp yet. The Chinese-American physicist K. Huang, for example, considers this is “one of the great mysteries of physics”. According to another renowned Anthony Zee, another Chinese-American physicist states in his Quantum Field Theory book “there may be something profound here that we have not quite understood.” According to British-American polymath Stephen Wolfram, he and the great American physicist Richard Feynman would often discuss “whether [the correspondence] was a coincidence or not.”

If the spacetime distance has this form we call it Euclidean spacetime. For flat spacetime, this procedure was given a rigorous framework by Arthur S. Wightman. However, in curved spacetime (for example, in the proximity of a massive body), problems occur regarding the associated symmetry group.
Nevertheless, some physicists believe that, in some sense, the “actual world” is represented by Euclidean spacetime.
Some physicists believe that, in some sense, the “actual world” is represented by Euclidean spacetime.
As discussed in the article, there are many reasons that could justify this point of view. Stephen Hawking, in his book A Brief History of Time, makes the following statement:

“One might think this means that imaginary numbers are just a mathematical game having nothing to do with the real world. From the viewpoint of positivist philosophy, however, one cannot determine what is real. All one can do is find which mathematical models describe the universe we live in. It turns out that a mathematical model involving imaginary time predicts not only effects we have already observed but also effects we have not been able to measure yet nevertheless believe in for other reasons. So what is real and what is imaginary? Is the distinction just in our minds?”

However, this perspective has some troublesome implications regarding fundamental notions about the properties of time and the notion of causality. Furthermore, treating time as a spatial dimension conflict with widely accepted theorems of quantum mechanics.
Maybe one day we will know the answer to this question. Or maybe not!
